title: Neutrophil-Lymphocyte Ratio (NLR) Calculator

ranges.interpretation: Normal neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio indicating no significant physiological stress
Mildly elevated NLR suggesting low-level physiological stress. Monitor clinical status and trend over time.
NLR indicates mild physiological stress. May be seen in mild infections, minor inflammatory conditions, or early stress response.
NLR indicates moderate physiological stress. Often seen in bacterial infections, significant inflammation, or moderate severity illness.
NLR indicates severe physiological stress. May indicate severe infection, sepsis, critical illness, or significant inflammatory conditions. Correlates with poor prognosis.

references: Zahorec R. Ratio of neutrophil to lymphocyte counts--rapid and simple parameter of systemic inflammation and stress in critically ill. Bratisl Lek Listy. 2001;102(1):5-14.
Yang AP, Liu JP, Tao WQ, Li HM. The diagnostic and predictive role of NLR, d-NLR and PLR in COVID-19 patients. Int Immunopharmacol. 2020 Jul;84:106504.
formula: NLR = Absolute Neutrophil Count / Absolute Lymphocyte Count
notes: Can be calculated using either absolute counts (cells/μL) or percentages
Higher NLR correlates with poor prognosis and higher mortality rates
More useful than standard white blood cell count for assessing physiological stress
Results can be skewed by steroid use, active hematologic disorders, or HIV-related chronic lymphopenia
Should be interpreted in clinical context and not in isolation
Can be trended over time for prognostication
